awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: A landscape resistance mapping approach to understanding species invasion patterns
awd_abstract_narration:
Global changes to natural communities are threatening biodiversity and ecosystem structure worldwide. Large numbers of species are transported globally through international trade and human traffic. Non-native species invade myriad habitats that include natural areas, agricultural landscapes, and timber forests, altering natural ecological communities, reducing ecosystem services, and causing economic losses that are estimated at up to billions of dollars annually. Damages and costs increase further as invasive species spread across larger regions. Understanding the conditions that facilitate and prevent range expansion are critical to both predicting the spread of invasive species and informing species conservation efforts. At species range edges, natural and human-assisted movement interplay with local population dynamics in complex ways to determine spread dynamics. This project centers on a fundamental question: What are the drivers of species range expansion and how do multiple processes interact to shape invasion patterns? Researchers will address this question by studying the invasion pattern of an infamous North American invader, the gypsy moth. The gypsy moth periodically defoliates large tracts of hardwood forest, negatively affecting ecological communities, timber production, and recreational activities. The gypsy moth invasion front stretches from Minnesota to North Carolina and is expanding at an average rate of approximately 10 kilometers per year. Knowledge gaps filled by this project will inform management and conservation strategies to ultimately reduce the environmental and economic costs of non-native invaders and maintain biodiversity in the United States.

The researchers will use an exhaustive spatiotemporal dataset that annually quantifies the 2000 km long range edge of the gypsy moth. This project combines cutting-edge landscape genetics with detailed analyses of local population dynamics to inform model simulations used to elucidate how local population processes, landscape connectivity, and anthropogenic movement of this species interact to drive spread patterns. The proposed research tests hypotheses associated with three main objectives: 1) quantify effects of landscape features and spatial covariance on the dynamics of low-density populations, 2) use spatial genetic lineages to understand how landscape features and human traffic patterns affect genetic structure and movement, and 3) integrate demographic and genetic information to determine how landscape features, human movement, and local population processes drive large-scale invasion patterns by simulating invasion on layered maps of population dynamic and movement parameters.

por.por_cntn:
Pest insects cause economic loss in crops and forests, damage natural environments, and bring new diseases. As an invasive pest insect spreads across a region, the magnitude of impacts increases. Thus, management of invasive insects often entails mitigation by slowing or reversing range expansion. Range expansion can be affected by a combination of environmental and human factors at local and regional scales. For example, favorable local weather conditions may increase range expansion, while habitat fragmentation may create barriers. Human population density and human movement patterns may increase range expansion through the inadvertent or intentional movement of pest species, for example, through long distance transport of firewood. Understanding the pathways to range expansion allows for informed management strategies that are cost-effective at suppressing range expansion of all invasive species. In this project, we advanced knowledge in the field of range expansion using a notorious forest pest in the United States, Lymantria dispar (gypsy moth), as a model system. 

Lymantria dispar (gypsy moth) defoliates up to millions of acres of forest annually in the United States, which sometimes results in tree mortality and causes economic loss to the timber industry, private landowners, and other stakeholders. L. dispar was introduced in the Boston MA area around 1870 and has been spreading primarily southerly to westerly since. The current invasion front stretches through the northern region (Minnesota and Wisconsin), central region (Illinois, Indiana, Ohio), and the southeastern region (West Virginia, Virginia, and North Carolina) of the eastern United States. L. dispar invasion in the United States is arguably the best documented biological invasion in the world through the annual application of tens of thousands of pheromone-baited traps along the entire invasion front. In this project, trap catches of L. dispar were utilized to assess which environmental and human factors facilitate or suppress range expansion across the invasion front.

Weather had the strongest effect on range expansion by L. dispar, but these effects differed between the northern, central, and southern regions. Low winter temperatures, particularly in the northern region, was the more important factor in suppressing range expansion, likely due to increased egg mortality in winter. High summer temperature suppressed range expansion in the southeastern and central regions, but increased range expansion in the northern region. Spring temperatures above ~30 C have been shown to increase mortality and decrease growth rates of L. dispar. High summer precipitation decreased range expansion in the northern and central regions, maybe because it creates favorable conditions for a parasitic fungus that causes high mortality in L. dispar.

The most important human factor affecting range expansion of L. dispar was human-caused fragmentation of forest habitat, which reduced rates of range expansion. In contrast, human population density was found to have only a small effect at increasing range expansion and only in the central region. Highway density, which is an indication of human movement patterns, and firewood use had no detectable effects on rates of range expansion.

This project advanced our understanding of the process of range expansion, revealing the relative roles of weather and human factors. Moreover, this project demonstrated that drivers of range expansion can differ among regions, highlighting the importance of developing region-specific management strategies. The effects of weather highlights how the invasibility of pest species may change under future climate change. Novel methods were developed that are generalizable to better understand population dynamics at range edges of a broad range of taxa. Information from this study is being communicated to forest managers in USDA Forest Service and state agencies to inform their management strategies for L. dispar so they can more effectively and efficiently mitigate range expansion through management and policy. The state agencies, in particular, work closely with the public, advising on best management practices that are informed by results from this project.
